title: 108_s562
content:
The "Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals Reorganization Act of 2003" establishes the former ninth circuit, new ninth circuit, and twelfth circuit. SEC. 3. The number and composition of circuits are amended, with changes to the ninth and twelfth circuits. SEC. 4. The number of circuit judges is also amended. SEC. 5 amends the table in section 48(a) of title 28, United States Code, by updating the places of the ninth and twelfth circuits to San Francisco, Los Angeles, Portland, and Seattle. SEC. 6 allows circuit judges from the former ninth circuit to elect to be assigned to the new ninth circuit or twelfth circuit. SEC. 7 states that the seniority of judges who elect to be assigned will run from their commission date. SEC. 8 applies these changes to cases. On the day before the effective date of this Act, any appeal or proceeding filed with the former ninth circuit will be handled accordingly. If the matter has been submitted for decision, further proceedings will continue as if the Act had not been enacted. If not submitted, the appeal or proceeding will be transferred to the appropriate court as if the Act had been in full force at the time of filing. The Act specifies that any appeal or proceeding filed with the former ninth circuit before the effective date of the Act will continue in the same manner as if the Act had not been enacted. Petitions for rehearing or re-hearing en banc will also be treated as if the Act had not been enacted. If a petition for rehearing en banc is granted, the matter will be reheard by a court as if the Act had not been enacted. SEC. 9. ADMINISTRATION.

Former ninth circuit may take administrative actions to carry out the Act and amendments. Former ninth circuit ceases to exist for administrative purposes on July 1, 2005. New ninth and twelfth circuits may meet in either jurisdiction for 10 years following enactment.

SEC. 10. EFFECTIVE DATE.

Act and amendments become effective on October 1, 2003.
